```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(adabag)
library(FNN)
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
breast <- read.csv("https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/breast-cancer/breast-cancer.data")
names(breast) <- c("Class","age","menopause","tumor.size","inv.nodes","node.caps","deg.malig","breast","breast.quad","irradiat")
form <- "Class ~ age + menopause + tumor.size + inv.nodes + node.caps + deg.malig + breast + breast.quad + irradiat"
#breast$Class <- as.numeric(breast$Class)
breast.numeric<-as.data.frame(sapply(breast,function(x) as.numeric(x)))
breast.factor<-as.data.frame(sapply(breast.numeric,function(x) as.factor(x)))
str(breast.factor)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure}
adaboost<-boosting(form, data=breast.factor, boos=TRUE, mfinal=20,coeflearn='Breiman')
summary(adaboost)
```

```{r}
errorevol(adaboost,breast.factor)
predict(adaboost,breast.factor)
t1<-adaboost$trees[[1]]
library(tree)
plot(t1)
text(t1,pretty=0)
```

```{r}
adaboost$weights
```

```{r}
knn.matrix <- get.knn(breast.numeric, k=7)
knn.matrix
```

```{r}
predict(adaboost$trees[1],breast.factor,type="class")
```
